    Surface Plotting

    spata-v2-plotting-surface.Rmd

    1. Introduction

    Surface plotting allows to visualize the barcode-spot’s information with a spatial dimension. Behind the scenes they are scatterplots whereby the x-aesthetic and y-aesthetic of the plot is mapped onto the respective coordinate-variable.

    # load packages
library(SPATA2)

# ggplot2 plots can be easily combined with 'patchwork'
library(patchwork) 

# load objects
human_cortex <- loadSpataObject("data/spata-obj-cortex265.RDS")
human_gbm <- loadSpataObject("data/spata-obj-gbm275.RDS")

# store example genes of interest as character vectors
genes_a <- c("TUBA1B", "HOPX", "PLP1", "ACTB")
genes_b <- c("CARTPT", "OLIG1", "GFAP", "SYNPR", "HOPX", "CCK")

    2. Basic surface plots one by one

    # plot a cluster feature
p1 <- 
  plotSurface(object = human_cortex,
              color_by = "seurat_clusters",
              pt_clrp = "npg",
              pt_size = 1.2) +
  ggplot2::labs(color = "Clusters")

# plot gene expression 
p2 <- 
  plotSurface(object = human_cortex, 
              color_by = "CARTPT",
              pt_size = 1.2,
              pt_clrsp = "magma")

# combine with patchwork 
p1 + legendTop() +
 p2 + legendTop()

    Figure 1.1. Basic surface plots

    The data.frame below shows the underlying data.frame. Note that two different variables were used with respect to the color-aesthetic.

    ## # A tibble: 3,676 x 6
##    barcodes           sample     x     y seurat_clusters    CCK
##    <chr>              <chr>  <dbl> <dbl> <fct>            <dbl>
##  1 AAACAAGTATCTCCCA-1 C265    444.  374. 2               0.426 
##  2 AAACACCAATAACTGC-1 C265    132.  434. 5               0.243 
##  3 AAACAGTGTTCCTGGG-1 C265    223.  525. 4               0.169 
##  4 AAACATTTCCCGGATT-1 C265    425.  446. 2               0.333 
##  5 AAACCCGAACGAAATC-1 C265    492.  341. 0               0.367 
##  6 AAACCGGAAATGTTAA-1 C265    527.  400. 0               0.361 
##  7 AAACCGGGTAGGTACC-1 C265    166.  323. 5               0.111 
##  8 AAACCGTTCGTCCAGG-1 C265    218.  388. 4               0.0663
##  9 AAACCTAAGCAGCCGG-1 C265    373.  472. 1               0.385 
## 10 AAACCTCATGAAGTTG-1 C265    132.  290. 5               0.376 
## # ... with 3,666 more rows

    Mapping continuous features on to the color-aesthetic is not always insightful, in particular if the plot is crowded - which is the case for every spatial-transcriptomic plot. In order to visualize the underlying pattern as well as to make the plot more aesthetically pleasing you can use the smooth-arguments.

    # plot gene expression 
p1 <- 
  plotSurface(object = human_cortex, 
              color_by = "CARTPT",
              pt_size = 1.2,
              pt_clrsp = "magma"
              )

# plot gene expression (spatially smoothed)
p2 <- 
  plotSurface(object = human_cortex, 
              color_by = "CARTPT",
              pt_size = 1.2,
              pt_clrsp = "magma",
              smooth = TRUE, 
              smooth_span = 0.2)

# combine with patchwork 
p1 + legendNone() +
p2 + legendTop()

    Figure 1.2. Not smoothed and smoothed surface plots in contrast

    3. Surface plots interactive

    Another more convenient way is to use plotSurfaceInteractive() which let’s you plot your figures interactively and way quicker. It returns a named list of all plots saved during your plotting session.

    # open application to obtain a list of plots
plots <- plotSurfaceInteractive(object = human_gbm)

    Figure 3.1 The interface of plotSurfaceInteractive()

    Figure 3.1 The interface of plotSurfaceInteractive() 

    # get plot names
names(plots)
    ## [1] "hypoxic_area" "metrn_high"
    # plot plots from returned list
# treat and post-process them like every other ggplot-object
plots$hypoxic_area + 
  ggplot2::labs(title = "Hypoxic Area") +
  legendNone() +
plots$metrn_high + 
  ggplot2::labs(title = "Formation of Axonal Networks (METRN)")

    Figure 3.2 Plots derived from plotSurfaceInteractive()


    4. Surface plots in comparison

    In order to quickly compare the spatial distribution of a set of variables of the same kind use plotSurfaceComparison().

    # compare gene expression on the surface
plotSurfaceComparison(object = human_cortex, 
                      color_by = genes_b,
                      smooth = TRUE, 
                      smooth_span = 0.2, 
                      pt_size = 0.6, 
                      pt_clrsp = "inferno")

    Figure 4.1 A quick way to compare several variables

    To visualize the averaged expression of a subset of genes use plotSurfaceAverage(). It takes either a named list of gene vectors or simply a vector of gene names.

    input_list <- list(Example1 = c("POSTN", "MARCH6", "FABP7", "TMSB4X"), 
                   Example2 = c("CCDC127", "FTL", "IGKC", "SPP1"), 
                   Example3 = c("ALDH3A2", "AQP1", "B2M", "IFIT1"), 
                   Example4 = c("GAPDH", "MT2A", "MT1X", "GLUL")
                   )

plotSurfaceAverage(object = human_gbm, 
                   color_by = input_list, 
                   smooth = TRUE, 
                   pt_size = 1)

    Figure 4.2 Average the expression of several genes
